document.masterDocTitle: The bee genus Colletes Latreille 1802 in Ethiopia (Hymenoptera: Apoidea: Colletidae)

mods:titleInfo.mods:title: The bee genus Colletes Latreille 1802 in Ethiopia (Hymenoptera: Apoidea: Colletidae)

heading.emphasis:
Key to the
Colletes
species of Ethiopia

subSubSection.paragraph:
The male of
C. aethiopicus Kuhlmann
sp. n.
is unknown. For the identification of males it is generally recommended and necessary for most species to dissect genitalia and especially S 7 . Due to variation in size and outer morphology the shape and size of S 7 is the easiest and most reliable character for the identification of the majority of species. For all species S 7 has been imaged at the same scale to facilitate rapid orientation and identification.

paragraph.keyLead:
1 Malar area elongate, much longer than width of base of mandible (cf.
Fig. 14
b); terga without distinct apical hair bands (
Fig. 15
b); large species ( 12â€“14 mm ); S 7 as in
Fig. 15
d................................................
C. latipes Friese

- Malar area not elongate, shorter than width of base of mandible; at least T 2 â€“T 5 with distinct apical hair bands; smaller species (< 12 mm )........................................................................................... 2

2 Hind basitarsus posteriorly with a dense crest of long hairs (
Fig. 13
c); S 7 as in
Fig. 13
d.............
C. somereni Cockerell
- Hind basitarsus without a dense crest of long hairs........................................................... 3

3 T 1 almost completely and densely covered with yellowish to orange short appressed hairs (
Fig. 11
b); S 7 as in
Fig. 11
c.........................................................................................
C. rothschildi
Va cha l
- T 1 without or only with few short appressed hairs, if densely covered with short appressed hairs than hairs white......... 4

4 Mesoscutal disc between punctures shagreened and matt; S 7 as in
Fig. 2
c........................
C. abessinicus Friese
- Mesoscutal disc between punctures smooth and shiny......................................................... 5

5 Disc of T 1 with abundant short appressed hairs (
Fig. 18
b); S 7 as in
Fig. 18
c...................
C. microdontus Cockerell
- Disc of T 1 either without or with very few short appressed hairs................................................ 6

6 T 1 apically narrowly brownish translucent (
Fig. 5
b); S 7 as in
Fig. 5
c....................
C. senkelensis Kuhlmann
sp. n.

- T 1 apically broadly yellowish translucent (
Fig. 9
b); S 7 as in
Fig. 9
c.......................
C. langano Kuhlmann
sp. n.

subSubSection.paragraph: In some species-groups it can be difficult to reliably identify the females without a reference collection. This especially applies to worn specimens where the pilosity is partly or entirely rubbed off.

1 Malar area elongate, much longer than width of base of mandible (
Fig. 14
b); terga without distinct apical hair bands (
Fig. 14
d); large species ( 12â€“14 mm )...................................................................

Figs 10
d, 17 d)... 3
